Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps L: Science Education for New Civic Engagements and Responsibilities (SENCER)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Educators or administrators invested in improving student outcomes in STEM, are constantly looking for proven, evidence-based, trusted sources worthy of their time and investment. They are aware of pedagogical advancements and are willing to do the work necessary to implement innovative practices. However, at many institutions, the financial climate and lack of professional development funding evidences the need for lower cost, yet high quality experiences and materials. For those who have no support, or must attend a disciplinary meeting instead with their limited allowance, webinars and e-friendly publications specifically provide accessible options to support their own professional development. This includes full-time faculty and the growing number of adjuncts. This proposal extends the benefits of a proven strategy by utilizing new technological platforms to promote broader adoption, increase equitable access, and promote program availability. Widely available and interactive webinars provide people with limited time or funds the opportunity to connect with experts from around the country for a reasonable cost and on a specific topic of need. Expanded applications of the proposed approach (Science Education for New Civic Engagements and Responsibilities) will lead to an exponentially larger number of students with strong scientific and quantitative literacy and more practitioners aware of an approach that responds to the challenges they face daily.

Since 2001 the Science Education for New Civic Engagements and Responsibilities (SENCER) project and the National Center for Science and Civic Engagement has developed and disseminated a range of educational products and professional development programs that support the improvement of formal and informal science education, including over 50 course models, "backgrounder" essays, peer-reviewed articles, residential and non-residential institutes and workshops, and a signature assessment tool (the SENCER SALG-Student Assessment of Learning Gains). All publications are currently digitized, tagged and searchable, and included in a web-accessed "digital library." In the project's most recent iteration new products are in development, including a webinar series, a series of workshops for faculty and administrators, a SENCER handbook, and course modules called "pearls of practice." This team believes that several of these products have commercial potential, either as benefits of a paid membership, and/or for individual download and sale.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Through the I-Corps grant, the SENCER (Science Education for New Civic Engagements and Responsibilities) initiative of the National Center for Science and Civic Engagement explored the development of potential products to support the improvement of student skill and interest in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics education through strong professional development grounded in validated research. Project personnel conducted 141 interviews with informal and formal education administrators, faculty, staff, graduate students, and K-12 administrators, educators, and parents to discern the challenges they face that SENCER and the National Center can address.

 

Results of interviews were analyzed and led to the refinement of the original hypotheses and to a more flexible, responsive collection of webinars, eBooks, and expanded campus consultation system to improve professional development and support formal and informal educators and administrators in their work to increase student skill, confidence, and engagement with STEM. Topics for webinars and eBook teaching manuals are drawn from needs cited by interviewees and from hundreds of participant responses on a symposium evaluation. Likewise, they have informed planning for new national and regional workshops. Live and pre-recorded interviews have been launched, and eBook style teaching manuals are in the final stages of design and testing before release to the public. A structure for a formal campus consultation program that includes compensation for faculty consultants is in the pilot stage, and will be refined over the next several months. Interview results also shaped the development and upcoming launch of an individual membership structure that will provide subscribers access to a full range of new materials, leadership pathways, and increased networking opportunities.

 

A selection of video recorded interviews are in the editing phase. Once complete, these interviews will be posted online as resources and examples of how the SENCER approach has been applied across disciplines and around the country to improve student STEM outcomes. They also offer diverse models of the capacious, complex civic issues that may be used in introductory to capstone courses.

 

The overarching goals that inform all NCSCE work, concerning I-Corps work as well as all prior and existing initiatives, are the improvement student learning, skills, and interest in STEM by helping them to easily understand the relevance of course work. This translates into students who are better able to apply their knowledge across disciplines while in school, and those who may do so later in as citizen scientists; in their careers, may they be in STEM or other professions; and just generally as citizens. NCSCE builds faculty capacity by conducting effective professional development, introducing educators to well-researched and evaluated strategies, and supporting a community of practice that continually works to break down barriers to STEM understanding and achievement.
